instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .
definitions.PP5V_S0_ALSCAM_F: What is PP5V_S0_ALSCAM_F? PP5V_S0_ALSCAM is a power rail for the webcam and the ambient light sensor..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
Working fine with an external monitor, Internal display is not detecting, Tried connecting another internal display but still no back light or image. 
History - Coffee spilled 
Found corrosion on display connector (Not on logic board but on display board). Cleaned it up , Still no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
Overvoltage went back to MLB through the video cable.
Compare diode mode to ground on the <SIGNAL>EDP_INT</SIGNAL> data lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL> - 0.216V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><0> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><0> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><1> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><1> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><2> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><2> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_P</SIGNAL><3> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_ML_N</SIGNAL><3> - 0.239V
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> - 1.120V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 0.553V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_ALSCAM_F</SIGNAL> - 0.441V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> - 0.550V

I found the one pin burned on the LCD connector(please find attachment), I don't have the schematic of the display board to figure out the net name.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1wjwrTH7vvYET_ySiMsF29bfYui3EZv4k?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL>/N must give almost same reading for diode mode to ground.
If not, CPU's eDP output is burnt; there is no series cap to protect it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
It may be a stupid question...
Is there any workaround for this signal? By wiring it from any of the USBC display data signals? Or only solution is to change motherboard?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
I can see similar signals on display mux page , For example <SIGNAL>DP_DDI2_ML_C_P</SIGNAL><0> .....<SIGNAL>DP_DDI2_ML_C_N</SIGNAL><3>  ,<SIGNAL>DP_DDI2_AUXCH_C_P</SIGNAL> / N , Will it make sense routing  it to internal display? ;)

Another question, Any idea about what activities take place by  <SIGNAL>EDP_INT_AUX_P</SIGNAL>/N. If it is not dynamically driven we can pull them into a high or low?
Because I can see there is a provision for a pullup and pulldown resisters <RESISTOR>R8502</RESISTOR>/3

.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
That is not just a simple DC signal.
Auxiliary port is used for communication between PCH and LCD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
I agree, 
Should I try feeding (display mux) inputs directly to display? 
for example  <CHIP>U3610</CHIP>.
 If you say it's not possible sad let's close the issue here

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
I don't really understand what you want to do.
The eDP bus is bad; you can't get image on internal LCD anymore.

<CHIP>U3610</CHIP> is dedicated for external DP, through Thunderbolt.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message: I mean , Can we replace the eDp bus with <SIGNAL>DP_DDI</SIGNAL>? What I understood <SIGNAL>DP_DDI</SIGNAL> is also display signals but not for internal display but for external. They multiplux and give for four USBC connectors. My question is , Can these signals drive internal display?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message:
Backlight is controlled by PCH and will not work, once eDP is damaged.
Internal LCD image and backlight are related.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Internal display not working, Booting , But no chime sound
threads.message: Ahhh Ok ., Got it,,,,, Sad let's close the thread
